channel.title: Run With Me
channel.description: You run, I run, now we run together.
channel.generator: Feeder 3 3.3.6(2864); Mac OS X Version 10.12.2 (Build 16C67) http://reinventedsoftware.com/feeder/

channel.itunes:author: Chris Krycho
channel.itunes:subtitle: A microcast about running, recorded while running. 3–5 minute episodes, released weekly-ish.
channel.itunes:summary: A microcast about running, recorded while running. In 3–5 minute episodes, released weekly-ish, I talk about it all: ups and downs, training, health, nutrition, motivation, racing, weird things your body does on long runs—everything.

item.title: 14: Welcome Back
item.description: I've been gone, courtesy of a temporarily non-functional microphone and a ridiculously crazy fall. Time to amp it back up for some triathlon and marathon training in 2017!
item.itunes:subtitle: I've been gone, but now I'm back!
item.itunes:summary: I've been gone, courtesy of a temporarily non-functional microphone and a ridiculously crazy fall. Time to amp it back up for some triathlon and marathon training in 2017!

item.title: 13: Training Volume/Don’t Be Dumb
item.description:
Keep your training volume increase reasonable---10--15% weekly, with a hard maximum of 20%. Failing to do so is a good way to end up sick (like I did).

Check out the run!
item.itunes:subtitle: Keep your training volume increase reasonable—10–15% weekly.
item.itunes:summary:
Keep your training volume increase reasonable—10–15% weekly, with a hard maximum of 20%. Failing to do so is a good way to end up sick (like I did).
Check out the run! https://www.strava.com/activities/665807331/embed/debc30d523461f1b18347ed54863874df9eabe53

item.title: [PRC]5: Recovery
item.description:
It's important to include rest in your training plan. Especially when you do extra-long runs.

Check out the run!

(You can see that accidental 20-mile long run here.)
item.itunes:subtitle: It's important to include rest in your training plan.
item.itunes:summary:
It's important to include rest in your training plan. Especially when you do extra-long runs.
Check out the run! https://www.strava.com/activities/646209790/embed/a6defccacf296f0d89aeb865edd7597804251b4d
(You can see that accidental 20-mile long run here: https://www.strava.com/activities/644619792.)

item.title: 12: A Training Plan
item.description:
A good mix of runs for half-marathon training.

  • Two or three aerobic runs, 4--6 miles long, run entirely aerobically.
  • One tempo run: 6--10 miles long, run 50% aerobically, 50% harder-than-race-heart-rate.
  • One day of speed work (800-meter repeats, or a quarter-mile hill workout), every other week, usually about 5--6 miles total.
  • One long run, approximately 80% done aerobically, with the last ~20% at "race heart rate".
  • One day of cross-training (a 30--45-minute bike ride).

Check out the run!
item.itunes:subtitle: A good mix of runs for half-marathon training.
item.itunes:summary:
A good mix of runs for half-marathon training.
- Two or three aerobic runs, 4--6 miles long, run entirely aerobically. - One *tempo run*: 6--10 miles long, run 50% aerobically, 50% harder-than-race-heart-rate. - One day of speed work (800-meter repeats, or a quarter-mile hill workout), every other week, usually about 5--6 miles total. - One long run, approximately 80% done aerobically, with the last ~20% at "race heart rate". - One day of cross-training (a 30--45-minute bike ride).
Check out the run! https://www.strava.com/activities/646209790/embed/a6defccacf296f0d89aeb865edd7597804251b4d

item.description:
12-mile runs without a water bottle are a bad idea.

item.title: 11: Avoiding Injury
item.description:
How to avoid getting injuries, or exacerbating mild ones, by listening to your body. (This is a recurring theme!)

Check out the run!

item.title: [PRC]3: Adapting on the Fly
item.description:
The opposite of the previous PRC: just as you sometimes go home early because your body is complaining, sometimes you stay out longer or run harder because your body is raring to go.

Check out the run!

item.description:

item.title: [PRC]2: Stopping
item.description:
Sometimes you go home from your run a mile or two early, because that's what's healthy and safe.

Check out the run!

item.title: 9: Consistency/Nutrition
item.description:
Two little topics:

  1. Consistency is tough especially when you're busy. Even when you fall behind, though, just get back out there.
  2. Health by way of nutrition is more than just calories-in and calories-out. How much you eat matters, but so does what you eat.

Check out the run!
item.itunes:summary:
Two little topics:
1. Consistency is tough especially when you're busy. Even when you fall behind, though, just get back out there.
2. Health by way of nutrition is more than just calories-in and calories-out. How much you eat matters, but so does what you eat.
Check out the run! https://www.strava.com/activities/592326197

item.title: 8. Far From Home
item.description:
Keeping at it even when you're on the road: it takes a lot of discipline, but it's also totally worth it.

I did the first three miles of this run with my dad!

Check out the run!

item.title: 7: Pushups and Pullups
item.description:
Running isn’t a great way to lose weight—you need to include strength training for that. But it is a great way to get healthy in general.

Check out the run!
item.itunes:summary:

item.title: 6: A Run is a Break
item.description:
How sometimes running makes you feel less physically tired, even when you start our incredibly tired physically. Counterintuitive? Maybe. But it's true anyway.

Check out the run!
